bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, May 11, 1942

div1.p: Wood comments on Walter Reed's letters and on Blossom Reed's attempts to sell them. She will send Hench a completed manuscript of her book to examine if he has time.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, May 11, 1942
div1.p:
Thank you so much for Blossom's ms. You were very nice to let
me have a look at it, and I can appreciatie your uneasiness.
You are rather in the position of the fomites fellows - nothing
bad was going to happen to them, but they couldn't be sure of
that until it was all over.

There were two or three things I should have liked to use, but
not very urgently. I thought one things was very sweet - how
shocked he was on the boat when the young man scolded his wife
because her hat blew off. He was so horrified that the loss of
a bonnet should be the occasion of harsh words and revolved that
nothing of the sort would ever happen with him & Emilie. As
you say, a lot of the letters are just too too. Obscurity has
compensations - people don't collect the letters that you wrote
when you were in your twenties. I'm sure Blossom will never
sell them in that form, and it will be so much the better for
Reed's memory if she doesn't.

As you know, I have that little jingle about the mosquito that
she quotes, but I got it from Gen. Kean's diary.

It amused me a great deal to see how, in the midst of being so
conscientiously high-flown and literary, Reed could suddenly say
something normal and and nice and funny - like in the long let-
ter about how he was sick in NY that was so filled with vague
lamentations and stuff he told about clashing with his landlady
and mentioned that she now knew what he thought about homeopathy,
spiritualism, abolitionism etc., and that he had a new address.
Did you see that Mr. Andrus died a week or two ago?

I'm supposed to finish - finally - this week and get the revised
ms to the publisher. It is bad enough to have to write a book,
without having to type the darned thing too. Crosy has turned
out to be a very good editor, which is very helpful to one as
addle-headed as I. I'd like to send you a carbon and if you
have time perhaps you will zip through it again to see if there
is anything glaring. The facts won't be changed, just the emph-
asis here and there in the last part, so if you haven't time to
look at it, don't feel that you should.

I'll mail you back the letters today or tomorrow, and I'm really
delighted to have seen them at last. Do you suppose I can refer
to them, list them I mean, in the bibliography? I should imagine
not, under the circumstances.
